==Japanese==
{{ja-kanjitab|座|敷}}

===Etymology===
A compound of {{compound|lang=ja|sort=さしき'|座|tr1=za|t1=sitting|敷|tr2=shiki|t2=spreading, covering}}, the stem noun form of verb {{m|ja|敷く|tr=shiku||to spread or lay out on the floor or ground}}.

Japanese houses originally had wood floors, and [[mat]]s or [[cushion]]s called {{l|ja|座|tr=''za''}} would be laid out ({{l|ja|敷く|tr=''shiku''}}) for sitting upon. Tatami ({{l|ja|畳}}) flooring did not become common until some time during the [[w:Muromachi period|Muromachi Period]], approximately 1337 to 1573.

===Pronunciation===
* [[重箱読み|Jūbakoyomi]]
* {{IPA|lang=ja|[za̠ɕiki]}}

===Noun===
{{ja-noun|ざしき}}

# a traditional [[Japanese]]-[[style]] [[room]] with [[tatami]] flooring, or in older times, with wood flooring and mats or cushions for sitting upon
# such a room used as a [[parlor]] to receive [[guest]]s
# by extension from the meaning of ''[[entertain]]ing'' {{m|en|guest|guests}}:
## a [[seat]] at a [[feast]] or [[party]]
## an [[invitation]] to a [[feast]] or [[party]]
## a [[feast]] or [[party]]
## {{lb|ja|sort=さしき'|euphemistic}} used by ''[[geisha]]'' and other entertainers, meaning a {{m|en|customer}} or {{m|en|patron}}
## {{lb|ja|sort=さしき'|Noh|archaic}} the [[audience]] of a [[Noh]] performance
